# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session
source.e83e737e:
observations = pd.read_csv('../input/biodiversity-in-national-parks-project/observations.csv')
species_info = pd.read_csv('../input/biodiversity-in-national-parks-project/species_info.csv')

data = pd.merge(observations, species_info, on='scientific_name')

print(data.head())
source.1ba6daf6:
species_num = species_info['scientific_name'].nunique()
print('There were {} different species observed'.format(species_num))
source.b392755b:
grouped_species = species_info[['category', 'scientific_name']].groupby('category').count()
print(grouped_species['scientific_name'])

grouped_species['scientific_name'].plot.bar()
plt.title('Number of Observed Species in Each Category', y=1.1, fontweight="bold")
plt.ylabel('Number of Species')
plt.xlabel('Categories of Species')
source.0845356d:
grouped_species['scientific_name'].plot.pie(radius=2, autopct='%1.0f%%', pctdistance=1.1, labeldistance=1.2)
plt.ylabel('')
plt.title('Proportion of Species per Category', y=1.5, fontweight="bold")
source.662b1936:
grouped_by_cat = data.groupby('category').sum()
print(grouped_by_cat)

sns.set_style('whitegrid')

ax = sns.barplot(cat_species,grouped_by_cat['observations'])
plt.title('Number of Observations in Each Category', y=1.1, fontweight="bold")
ax.set_ylabel('Number of Observations')
ax.set_xlabel('Categories of Species')
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
plt.tight_layout
source.f8d05206:
grouped_multiple = data[['category', 'park_name','observations']].groupby(['category', 'park_name']).agg({'observations': 'sum'})
grouped_multiple.columns = ['observation_sum']
grouped_multiple = grouped_multiple.reset_index()


fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(11.7, 8.27))
sns.barplot(ax=ax, x = grouped_multiple.category, y = grouped_multiple.observation_sum, hue=grouped_multiple.park_name)
plt.title('Number of Observations in Each Category', y=1.1, fontweight="bold")
ax.set_ylabel('Number of Observations')
ax.set_xlabel('Categories of Species')
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
plt.tight_layout
plt.legend(title='National Parks', loc='upper left')
plt.show()
source.b998c06d:
observations_grouped = data[['park_name','observations']].groupby('park_name').sum()
print(observations_grouped)

ax = sns.barplot(parks,observations_grouped['observations'])
plt.title('Number of Observations in Each National Park', y=1.1, fontweight="bold")
ax.set_ylabel('Number of Observations')
ax.set_xlabel('National Park')
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
plt.tight_layout
plt.show()
source.bbd11c2d:
status = data.conservation_status.unique()
status = status[1:]
status.sort()

print(status)
source.1fc006dd:
status_grouped = data[['conservation_status', 'scientific_name']].groupby('conservation_status').count()
print(status_grouped)
print('Total number of species: '+str(len(data['conservation_status'])))
print('Number of species with conservation status: '+ str(status_grouped['scientific_name'].sum()))
percentage = status_grouped['scientific_name'].sum() / len(data['conservation_status'])*100
percentage = percentage.round(1)
print('Percentage of species with conservation status: {}%'.format(percentage))

ax = sns.barplot(status,status_grouped['scientific_name'])
plt.title('Number of Species in Each Conservation Status', y=1.1, fontweight="bold")
ax.set_ylabel('Number of Species')
ax.set_xlabel('Conservation Status')
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
plt.tight_layout
plt.show()
source.794a99cf:
grouped_multiple = data[['category', 'scientific_name','conservation_status']].groupby(['category', 'conservation_status']).agg({'scientific_name': 'count'})
grouped_multiple.columns = ['scientific_name_sum']
grouped_multiple = grouped_multiple.reset_index()
print(grouped_multiple)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(11.7, 8.27))
sns.barplot(ax=ax, x = grouped_multiple.category, y = grouped_multiple['scientific_name_sum'], hue=grouped_multiple.conservation_status)
plt.title('Number of Species in Each Category by Conservation Status', y=1.1, fontweight="bold")
ax.set_ylabel('Number of Species')
ax.set_xlabel('Categories of Species')
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
plt.tight_layout
plt.legend(title='National Parks', loc='upper left')
plt.show()
source.ed552719: Conclusion: The relative distribution of observations of each national park is the approximately the same throughout all categories!

source.7a03dc15: Conclusion: "Nonvscular Plant" is the category with the most observations by far. Comparing it to the "Vascular Plant" (which is the category with the most species) category shows that some species are observed significantly more often than others.

source.670dceec:
Questions:

Species:
1. How many different species were observed?
2. What categories of species were observed?
3. How many species are observed in each category?
4. What are 10 the most observed species?
5. What is the most observed category of species?
6. What species occur in the most parks?

Parks:
1. How many parks made observations?
2. Which are these parks?
3. How many observations did each park make?
4. How many different species did each park observe?
5. Is there a relationship between number of species observed and number of observations?

Conservation Status:
1. What are the different conservation status?
2. How many species are in each conservation status?
3. Which category of species has the highest proportion of endangered species?
source.c5a03217: Conclusion: Every Species occurs in all of the four national parks!
source.6eca5922: Conclusion: There is no relationship between number of species observed and number of observations, because all four national parks observe the same amount of species but have a different amount of observations. Therefore it is plausible to say that the Yellowstone National Park does the most intensive observations. This fact should be considered when making budgeting decisions.
source.885194f7: Conclusion: The category "Vascular Plant" contains by far the most observed species. This either shows that most observed species fall in to this category or the species of this category are likelier to be observed. Further investigation is needed.
